James Bond author Ian Fleming came up with a brilliant supervillain with the mad Auric Goldfinger. His scheme to radiate and devalue the gold within Fort Knox is creative and clever for a novel concept. It's all about Goldfinger's own gold being increased in value and hurting American currency value on behalf of Auric Goldfinger's the Communist Chinese allies. Fleming creates crafty and edgy ideas from killing off the Bond girl to Bond getting captured and used by Goldfinger for his fiendish plot. Screenwriters Richard Maibaum, Berkely Mather, and Paul Dehn create witty one liners for Bond to spout to taunt his enemies, while also writing romantic dialogue for when Bond is being a cad towards Pussy Galore or the other Bond girls here..

Sean Connery continues to astonish and delight as English secret agent James Bond. Connery is the ideal James Bond. Connery kills it for the intricate action choreography, charming flirtations with Pussy Galore, and hilarious insults to Gert Fröbe's massive Bond villain Goldfinger. Fröbe's Goldfinger is entertaining as the amiable Goldfinger as he gives Bond every chance to escape and thwart his evil plot. His clear hatred of Bond is shown in his smears and scowls. I love his legendary line, "No Mr. Bond, I expect you to die!" that's delivered with a menacing cavalier glee. Goldfinger is overly confident in his convoluted plan to attack Fort Knox in a brazen move by a fearsome foe. Alongside Harold Sakata's deliriously fun toadie Oddjob, Goldfinger brings on the evil. His imposing stature and neat hat throws always entertain me whenever Oddjob smirks or strikes out against Bond.

Honor Blackman is so dreamy and flirty as Goldfinger's unforgettable Bond girl Pussy Galore. She's captivating as a villainess, stern as James Bond's love interest, and skilled as an ace pilot. She's drop dead gorgeous with a voluptuous figure, lovely translucent blue eyes, cute golden locks, an elegant English accent, and a sheer confidence most Bong girls could never quite compare. Honor Blackman remains one of the prettiest and coolest Bond girls as her enchanting Pussy Galore. 

Shirley Eaton is breathtaking as the sultry Bond girl Jill Masterson in her black bikini against her pale white skin. Her playful flirting with Bond is fun and it's still shocking seeing her stunning figure all painted in glossy gold. Tania Mallet is so pretty and charming as Tania Masterson with her sniper rifle, fast driving, and all black jumpsuit. Bernard Lee is funny as the dry British humored MI6 chief M. Lois Maxwell is the perfect Miss Moneypenny with her cute flirting with Sean Connery's Bond. Desmond Llewelyn is even funnier as MI6's equipment head, who gives Bond a tricked out Aston Martin luxury car with the works and a few neat tracking gadgets. Cec Linder is nice as CIA agent Felix Leiter, who aids Bond on his golden quest. Margaret Nolan gets a sweet cameo as the blonde Bond girl Dink in a bikini massaging Bond by a pool. Mai Ling must be mentioned as the sultry Asian stewardess Mei-Lei, who Pussy Galore orders to spy on Bond in a humorous sequence.

Production designer Ken Adam's sets are all magnificent with lavish estates and bases of Goldfinger's, but I'm especially pleased by Goldfinger's moving lounge where he shows his fellow crooks his maps and plans to knock off Fort Knox. Freda Pearson's 60's furniture is all warm in color and still stylish for its era. Art direction from Peter Murton, Maurice Pelling, and Michael White create elaborate bases of operation for Goldfinger and luxury planes for Pussy Galore to fly.

Composer John Barry provides Goldfinger with a lush sound score that soothes you with his sensual melodies, and gives you a rush of adrenaline for his exuberant rushes of notes. Shirley Bassey sets the standard for powerful vocal performances for James Bond themes for the foreseeable future with her outstanding singing on "Goldfinger." She has a rich voice to match Auric Goldfinger's finer tastes. John Barry's orchestration for the song is equally lush and befitting a lavish Rick Ross rap beat, like only fans with expensive taste could truly appreciate. What a fantastic Bond theme. It's so extravagant and bombastic with an eerie undertone. Sound designers Gordon K. McCallum and Dudley Messenger provide rushes of air when Oddjob throws his hat to massive car explosion noises and more for Goldfinger.

Make-up artists Paul Rabiger and Basil Newall give each lady a stunning glow with cute blush and incredible volume for their hair. Pussy Galore's black jumpsuit in her plane to her chic purple pants suit are all so sexy and flattering on Honor Blackman. Oddjob and Bond's tuxedos from Anthony Sinclair are fitted and stylish, while Goldfinger's German aesthetic suits are fitting for his actor's Germanic heritage and style.

Overall, Goldfinger is a blast and as interesting and dynamic as James Bond movies can muster.

It took until the third installment of the Ian Fleming-based James Bond spy movie franchise for its identity to crystallize. Following on the successful heels of Dr. No and From Russia with Love- both directed by Terence Young, Sean Connery's early mentor for the urbane leading role - Goldfinger marked a significant upgrade in production values that would make everything about the franchise iconic. Budgeted at more than the cost of the first two films combined, Goldfinger launched the ritual of beginning each subsequent Bond film with a stand-alone mission sequence for the fictional British MI6 agent, known by his code number 007, to show off his stuff. Other customs follow. An assignment meeting with British Secret Service head M allows for the otherwise autonomous Mr. Bond to have his feathers clipped while being informed of his latest mission. A little office flirtation with M's secretary Ms. Moneypenny segues into a meeting with resident gadget master Q, who gets Bond up to speed on the state-of-the-art devices that the audience can expect to see employed throughout the movie. From here on, female characters would be sexier and more dangerous, yet also more likely to die. Exotic set pieces would be epic in scale. The series' signature nuanced tone, straddling dualities such as dry humor and outrageous danger, would be more pronounced. Goldfinger is practically the template for the modern action blockbuster, yet still it's impossible to hate. In fact, it's deucedly hard not to love, simply because everything it does, it does so much better than its inheritors. A handful of other Bond flicks qualify as more "serious" suspense, and one (Skyfall) even borders on flawless. But Goldfinger will always be the best, for the same reason the Beatles will always be the best rock act and Peanuts will always be the best American comic strip: It's a phenomenon that defines its category.

You know how when sometimes you watch a movie and you're like, "I've seen that a thousand times." Well, chances are, that thing you've seen so often probably came from this third installment in the James Bond franchise. That's right, in this movie we're given super cool car with all the spy trimmings, the lethal bowler hat, and the tuxedo underneath the wetsuit.

If Dr. No was a detective story, and From Russia with Love was a action movie, then this movie, Goldfinger, is not only a spy movie as we know them today, but the one that spawned all the rest of the spy movies to come. 

Now, I didn't see the word Goldfinger written on any document or doorway in the film except in the title cards, so I was wrong about that in my previous podcast, but the other James Bond staples still held true, from the gun barrel to the opening action scene, and so on. 

And this opening action scene really does pull me right into the movie much more than the previous two movies did. Seeing the assassin's reflection in the girl's eyeball, tossing the electrical fan in the bathtub — which we'll see foreshadows another death that we'll get to — this is the stuff I sign up for when turning on a spy movie. And then it gets even better after the opening credits. 

I love how Bond is spying on the Gin game that Goldfinger is playing, making him loose. But let's talk about Goldfinger for a moment. I admit I was disappointed to see that he was just a bumbling rich old man who clearly wasn't going to be any physical match for Bond, but we'll talk about if his mind was a match for Bond. 

Of course Bond bangs the blonde working for Goldfinger, but I've got say, with as disposable as these girls are, I can't buy that he's at all that upset when he finds her dead golden body on the bed — it just doesn't seem like a believable motivation for him to go after Goldfinger. But let's talk about her dying by suffocation. I really don't think that's a thing, like your body can't suffocate because your skin can't breathe. Jim Carrey survived all the makeup from the Grinch, and Eddie Murphy as the Klumps. I'm just not buying that dead any more than I buy that Bond is emotionally disturbed by her murder. 

But who presumably killed her? Goldfinger's henchman, Oddball. That's the bowler hat guy! Disney parodies this a lot, and the most stark reference that kept standing out to me was when Mr. Potato Head used his hat to stop the sliding doors from closing in Toy Story 2. But this is the kind of thing you see so often that you never stop to think about where it originated from, and it was right here. 

And let's not forget, James Bond has been showing himself as a hat tosser as well, as he makes it a habit to toss his hat on the rack whenever he's in Pennymoney's waiting room. 

And I'm so happy to finally be taken into Q Branch for the first time. And I'm even happier to be shown just how badass his car is! From the ejector button to the rotating license plate, this is all incredibly fun stuff! Now, I've always wanted a green Jurassic Park jeep, you know the ones where they drive on the tour that the T-rex destroys, but this movie gets me dangerously close to wanting a DB5 even more, especially after the car chase we see later on. 

I do love the golfing scene. It's nothing really you have to think about, it's just all set up as a joke, where Bond gets the best of Goldfinger, which will further fuel Goldfinger's vendetta against Bond. And this is where Oddball shows us his lethal talent with his hat, and I buy it, especially since Oddball never says a word in the whole movie. He's just all brute and threat, and I love it. I am, however, disappointed that he doesn't actually chop anyone's head off later like he demonstrated with that statue. But I do appreciate that the threat is there. 

And then we get a car chase scene, which isn't the big one quite yet, but it does feature the tire-stabbing hubcaps, and Bond meets the sister of the girl who was gilded at the beginning. And then once he picks her up, another more exciting car chase ensues, and this really does kick ass and we get to see the DB5 in all its glorious action, from releasing the blinding gas to spraying liquid, to ejecting his passenger — the only thing it didn't do was lift itself up on stilts for the oncoming car to pass underneath. Still, the Batmobile has nothing on this incredible. car. 

But as incredible as it is, Bond still gets captured because of a trick mirror. And he finds himself in Goldfinger's laboratory, strapped to a table, with a lethal laser beam pointed at him. Now this scene was incredibly suspenseful! I kept trying to figure out how he was going to get out of this situation, and I just couldn't. I even love how indifferent Goldfinger was to him dying. Bond would try to negotiate, and Goldfinger just carried on with his scientists in idle chitchat. I could even go so far as to say that this is one of the greatest suspense scenes out there.

Luckily he's saved by remembering two words: Operation Grand Slam. And Bond plays it smart. Are you willing to take that chance that 008 knows as much as I do? He'll replace me on the field and you won't know who he is. 

Now, Bond may have gotten out of this situation, but it's very odd that he spends literally the rest of the movie in captivity, AND he struggles to bag the next woman he meets. You'd think a woman named Pussy Galore would be more than happy to show him her — well, she eventually does, but it takes more work than Bond is used to exerting. 

On that note, is his penis just made of super hero juice of some sort? If I have one ding against this franchise, it's that his magic Weiner seems to get him out of any situation so long as his hands aren't shackled so he can drop his pants. 

Maybe that's part of the charm of James Bond, I don't know. But to me, I see it as a crutch for the movies to fall on in when there's no other way for him to fight. It's funny enough though, that's it's not ruinous. 

But you know what's NOT charming? That this movie's exotic location is Kentucky. That's where I live now, and let me tell you, there's nothing exotic about this place beyond the few grass fields they show. And then they make it look even trashier by showing us dumpy main streets and lots of Kentucky Fried Chicken. Sure there's a couple of horses and mint julep on the front porch, but if they're going to Kentucky, why not have a scene on steam boat or something to give it a little more appeal? 

But we're in Kentucky to break into Fort Knox so that Goldfinger can get his hands on all the gold. And let's remember, Bond is still in captivity, which is really shocking. He's merely reactionary for most of this movie, which I guess isn't much different from Marty McFly in the Back to the Future movies, I suppose, but I expect James Bond to be the man to really steer events. 

Regardless of all of this, I'm still having loads of fun. He attacks his jail guard, Goldfinger transforms his speakeasy into a conference room, which really freaks out his money guys, there's lots of fun to be had here. I'm liking the humor, I'm liking Felix and his partner trying to keep up with Bond, but it's almost heartbreaking to see Bond's car smashed into a cube, as cool as that was to watch. 

And I know I've lightly complained about Bond being held captive throughout the rest of this movie, but it was fun wondering how in the world he was going to save the day, but Bond did break out of his cuffs just long enough to beat Oddball in a callback to when he tossed the electric fan in the bathtub at the beginning, because he really was no match for Oddball. And I did think it was funny that he had no hat throwing skills when it really mattered. 

And I found it interesting that it wasn't actually him who saved the day be turning the bomb off, it was somebody else.

Goldfinger getting sucked out of the plane was just a little too cartoony to me, just as it was cartoony in Alien, but I go with it. I only wish they would make those windows just a little bit bigger so it'd be easier for me to buy into it. 

And just like the previous Bond movies it ends with Bond banging it out with the Bond girl, and the movie's over. 

Now let's rate this movie. This one's easy for me to rate. Is it a better movie than Dr. No and From Russia with Love? It's better than Dr. No, but From Russia with Love is still a finer, more sophisticated film. If I may make a contemporary comparison, if From Russia with Love is Captain America: Winter Soldier, then Goldfinger is Guardians of the Galaxy. It's sillier, and not to be taken seriously, and it involves really no brain power. But, it's more fun. And that's what I want in my movies, that's how I judge them. How much fun they are often determines the rewatch ability factory. And of all the Bond movies I'd re-watch that I've reviewed so far, it would be this one hands down. So I putting Goldfnger on my list at number 3.

It took until the third installment of the Ian Fleming-based James Bond spy movie franchise for its identity to crystallize. Following on the successful heels of Dr. No and From Russia with Love- both directed by Terence Young, Sean Connery's early mentor for the urbane leading role - Goldfinger marked a significant upgrade in production values that would make everything about the franchise iconic.
Budgeted at more than the cost of the first two films combined, Goldfinger launched the ritual of beginning each subsequent Bond film with a stand-alone mission sequence for the fictional British MI6 agent, known by his code number 007, to show off his stuff. Other customs follow. An assignment meeting with British Secret Service head M allows for the otherwise autonomous Mr. Bond to have his feathers clipped while being informed of his latest mission. A little office flirtation with M's secretary Ms. Moneypenny segues into a meeting with resident gadget master Q, who gets Bond up to speed on the state-of-the-art devices that the audience can expect to see employed throughout the movie. From here on, female characters would be sexier and more dangerous, yet also more likely to die. Exotic set pieces would be epic in scale. The series' signature nuanced tone, straddling dualities such as dry humor and outrageous danger, would be more pronounced.
Goldfinger is practically the template for the modern action blockbuster, yet still it's impossible to hate. In fact, it's deucedly hard not to love, simply because everything it does, it does so much better than its inheritors. A handful of other Bond flicks qualify as more "serious" suspense, and one (Skyfall) even borders on flawless. But Goldfinger will always be the best, for the same reason the Beatles will always be the best rock act and Peanuts will always be the best American comic strip: It's a phenomenon that defines its category.

The third Bond film has been hailed by many critics as the Bondiest one of all, therefore ultimately the best in the series.  Unfortunately, they're wrong, and the movie is among the dullest of the Sean Connery 007s.  Why, you may ask?  So many reasons; but before we get to that, I'll roughly sketch out the plot. 

After a pre-intro credit sequence (the sequence being a particularly memorable highlight in the film), Bond finds himself in Miami spying on a gold dealer named Goldfinger, a brilliant criminal mastermind, and the movie's chief antagonist.  Bond finds Goldfinger poolside at a posh hotel where he's inexplicably cheating at gin rummy with the help of a telephoto lens wielding assistant (did I mention it's a sexy girl?) in a nearby hotel room who is feeding him his opponents cards via radio earpiece. Bond goes upstairs, and sexes her over to his side, and then is knocked out by Korean enforcer, and cheapest character in Goldeneye deathmatch, Oddjob.  When he wakes up, the girl he sexed earlier is dead and covered in gold paint.  Oops.

The film then transports Bond to merry ol' England, where he beats him at golf, then scenic Switzerland, where he discovers one of Goldfinger's evil plans, then on a private plane flown by Pussy Galore, the first of many ridiculously named Bond girls, and then finally to ... uh... rural Kentucky.  Yeah.  It's here that 007 learns the true nature of Goldfinger's devious plan: detonating an atomic device in Fort Knox, irradiating the US gold supply, and increasing his personal net worth in doing so. 

Now let's get to the meat of why this movie is dull as hell when it comes to Bond films.  First, there's an unnecessary long golf match, which is supposed to show how cunning Bond is, but was much more effective in the novel than it is on screen.  Secondly, after being put up against villains like Dr. No, Donald "Red" Grant, and the mysterious Number 1, being put up against an overweight ginger obsessed with Gold and his stocky Korean stereotype is a bit over the line.  The characters in general are simultaneously unbelievable and kitschy, but the plot attempts to take itself seriously, creating a continual contradiction that leaves the audience wondering if they should be laughing, or held in suspense.  This is visually supplemented by moments where footage of on-location filming is intercut with clearly green screened shots where there is absolutely no fathomable rationale for it to be occurring.      
 
A good example of this is Goldfinger's harebrained scheme for getting his atomic device into Fort Knox: having Pussy Galore fly above the compound with five planes and release a nerve gas over the area killing all the guards, completely ignoring the fact that this wouldn't affect anyone inside a building, the amount of dispersion that would occur in the attempt, the concept of gas masks, and the difficult to factor conditions like wind, humidity and precipitation.  The way that Bond outwits Goldfinger's scheme is even more ridiculous and puts the movie into the over-the-top camp department of cinema, which is absurd and, considering it's the final act of the film, feels almost intellectually offensive to the viewer. 
 
But if you can suspend your disbelief throughout all of that, you still have to wonder how a brilliant criminal mastermind like Goldfinger is actually a bumbling con artist that can't beat Bond in even the simplest of attempts.  It makes you really start to question how he got to be so powerful in the first place, and how nearly every female agent he has in his employ is so quick to turn on him when a dashing British agent comes along offering nothing but a one night stand in exchange to their presumably high-salary position. 

Nearly half of the film takes place in Kentucky, since this is where the meat and potatoes of the plot is taking place, and boy, oh boy, is it a fucking snore.  Rather than cavorting in high class hotels, high roller casinos, and high alcohol bars, Bond has to stay on a ranch in rural southern America not doing much of anything.  There is possibly no place in the entire franchise where the character is more out of his element, and it clashes so severely with the mythos that you're left simultaneously scratching your head and wondering when it will all just end.   

TL;DR - 5/10

Unlike previous installments in the series, which had lower budgets, this movie relies on hat tips to fans and doesn't attempt to create a movie that stands well on its own two feet.  Much of this movie's success has to be based on nostalgia, and the established status that it already has, but if you go back to watch it now, grab an energy drink, cause it's a total slog.

The gold-plated edition of early Bond, this perfectly shaken martini of devastating wit, action, and intrigue also introduces some lasting finishing touches to the franchise all of its own. Ironically, it bares noting from the get-go that this was the first 007 flick to use the line "A martini...shaken, not stirred" as a calling card for the suavest and deadliest of superspies. Dr. No and From Russia with Love established the brand but Goldfinger put all of the elements to their most brilliant effect and gives all future 4-Star Bond chapters a run for their Moneypenny. 

In this, the quintessential 007 film, James Bond (Connery) uncovers a plot to contaminate the Fort Knox gold reserve while investigating a gold magnate's (Gert Frobe) smuggling empire. 

Though his spyware started a slippery slope into camp from this film on (inflating dart in Live and Let Die; the invisible car in Die Another Day), the geeky gadgets keep up the cheeky cheer in this outing, Bond's seagull-hat disguise, Oddjob's (himself, one of the great series henchmen) steel-rimmed hat, and Goldfinger's laser among the best. Also, Q's laboratory first gets walked through, the Aston Martin first gets driven, and a pre-title action sequence first kicks off a new spy adventure (Robert Shaw choking out a foot solider wearing a Bond mask in From Russia with Love just doesn't count). Of all of the early films and their lasting effect on pop culture, Goldfinger uses all of the tricks in Bond's exploding briefcase to the most well-rounded heights. The tone, humor, casting, and action sequences fire on all cylinders in a perfect full circle of crazy cool entertainment. Future Bond movies would boast better examples of each of these elements but the 3rd film uses them consistently well and its riff-worthiness in the Internet age only speaks volumes as to its longevity and ability to kill audiences. 

Bottom line: Midas Touche

If you are the person that loves the fun in Bond, the camp and the outlandish, and why should you? Then this is the one that started it all. Yes Bond may have already firmly established himself in 2 previous outings but for some Goldfinger is the quintessential Bond movie and although I believe it to be a brilliant piece of cinema, for me it has never, even having watched it many times through my life, been what everyone hypes it up to be. Is that to say its bad, of course not. Goldfinger goes bold, it goes large, it gets the ball rolling thick and fast. While Bond is on, what he believe to be, holiday to Miami, he bumps into his old friend Felix Lieter, who asks him to observe a potential threat to national security Auric Goldfinger, soon however Bond finds himself biting off more than he can chew, as people around him start dying and he himself soon falls victim to Goldfingers grand plot. Goldfinger starts us off with some completely redundant mission, that never feels important or interesting, more convieniant and from then on minor gripes just continue throughout. I'll get the positive out of the way, Goldfinger is the first Bond movie to have a Bond theme, sung blisteringly by Shirley Bassie, it has turned the action, for that decade, up to 11 and has really upped the comedy value. Bond is now lighter than before with jokes aplenty, some brilliant, some not so much and completely hilarious over the top villain shenanigans. Bond himself is utterly fantastic, its clear as day now that Connery is relishing in every moment he gets to be Bond and he chews the screen up every chance he gets. The film also includes some wonderfully quirky characters, in the form of Pussy Galour, yes you read that right and Oddjob, they are iconic and extremely memorable. What the film does have, however is just everything that became preposterous about the franchise. A villain who although, always seems to be miles ahead of Bond, still decides to keep him alive and a decoration to his plan because... Well, just because. Goldfinger explains his operation to Bond, which proves to be detrimental as one might expect, in what the franchise is now ripped to shreds for, the old tell the good guy the plot before killing him, in such a way that he will escape. What adds more insult to injury is that Bond vanishes for a large chunk of this movie, deciding to pull the focus onto Goldfinger, a character who is so well written but so poorly acted by Gert Frobe. Goldfinger feels like a comedy bad guy and it sadly diffuses any tension that should be there, especially when Bond is being duped at every turn. Luckily the threat comes in the shape of Oddjob, if not emotionally but physically. I also have a huge gripe with the over abundance of screen work done on this film. There are huge segments where its so frighteningly clear that actors are having a conversation, in a studio, in front of a screen. I can excuse this during a car chase, I cant when you background is a group of people sun bathing, it cannot be that hard to achieve, you must have filmed it at some point, why not film the entire scene there instead. Maybe its down to time but its seriously noticable and hilariously criminal. The film does survive however and as the entity it is, is a hugely fun and bombastic experience, its not perfect and it lacks the tension that the first 2 films have. Although it is a welcome change to have more memorable characters and set pieces and having Bond go bold once in a while is not a bad thing, you cant help but feel this film opened up a huge can of worms. Essential yes, hugely overrated, hell yes.

The Bond franchise finds its long-term footing in this third installment, striking a masterful balance between larger-than-life characters, silly overindulgence and skilled espionage work - a tricky combination that doesn't usually work. Where Dr. No and From Russia With Love were deathly serious, concentrating heavily on suspense, Goldfinger is far less afraid to kick back and have a little fun when the opportunity arises. There's definitely a healthy dose of the 1960s at play here, from the fashions on display to the attitudes of those wearing them, but in almost every single instance that results in a stronger, more vibrant cast. Despite their appallingly silly names, Oddjob, Pussy Galore and even Goldfinger himself are thoroughly deep, interesting, remarkable characters with a lot going on beneath the surface. The exploration of each villain's unique nooks and crannies, paired with an intensely curvy, unpredictable plot and the unmistakable presence of Bond himself, provides more fuel than any film could reasonably require. Quick in wit and in pace, it covers a lot of ground with admirable efficiency, leaves us with two fistfuls of memorable moments, and raises the stakes to staggering heights. It's no wonder this is the standard by which all other Bonds are judged.

There's reason behind why this Bond film is the famous out of all the films. Perhaps the most iconic Bond film ever made.  Goldfinger is one of the few Bond films to effectively capture and combine the gritty spy elements of the novels with the flashy, larger-than-life elements that have become a staple of the film series.  The fantastic and light-hearted elements win out in the end, but it's a good balance.  I have always preferred the darker, more plausible nature of the books, but the appeal of the films goes far beyond that, and it's an important reason why the Bond legacy has lasted as long as it has.  The film itself throws everything it has at the audience, immersing the viewer in the exciting, colorful, and dangerous world of 007.  Gert Frobe plays a delightfully menacing Auric Goldfinger, and Honor Blackman's Pussy Galore is one of the most memorable Bond girls in history, even if it's strictly because of the name.  Oddjob's brute physicality makes him a formidable henchman, but we never get to see him unleash his full bad self.  Other iconic Bond moments are introduced, including the first appearance of Q branch and the Aston Martin DB5 with "a few optional extras".  Connery's Bond is almost perfect, even if he lacks some of the bad-ass characteristics of the previous entry.  Still, he's only guy in the world who can pull off his spy outfit to reveal a perfectly pressed tuxedo underneath.
